since_last_update: Dominant macro change: US January CPI came in softer than expected on the headline (0.2% m/m vs 0.3% est; annual CPI 2.4% vs ~2.5% est), shifting the near-term risk from “upside CPI / higher real yields” toward “downside CPI / lower yields” (WSJ; AP).

Rates impulse: softer CPI + easing core trend (core CPI 2.5% y/y; core 0.3% m/m) supports a modest dovish repricing in policy-path expectations and tends to benefit duration-sensitive equity factors (growth/NDX) and gold via lower real-rate pressure (WSJ).

Risk-premium overlay: prior-session equity tape featured an AI-related de-risking narrative and large end-of-day sell imbalance flows, which can leave fragile positioning even if CPI is supportive (Reuters; Yahoo Finance).

Policy/trade backdrop improved at the margin for semis: US–Taiwan finalized a trade agreement confirming a 15% tariff rate and broader commitments that can be read as incremental supply-chain relief/supportive for semis vs broader tariff uncertainty (Reuters; FT).
today_focus: Primary driver today: post-CPI rates repricing (lower yields / softer inflation impulse) vs residual “AI/tech volatility” de-risking from the prior session—watch which one dominates index futures direction into cash open (WSJ; Reuters).

Equity factor map: NQ sensitivity to real yields remains the key transmission; if rates rally persists, it should mechanically support duration equities, but fragile sentiment from the AI-led selloff raises whipsaw risk (Reuters; Yahoo Finance).

Gold focus: near-term direction should still be governed by real-rate/FX follow-through after CPI; the CPI downside surprise is directionally supportive unless risk-off deleveraging creates forced liquidation (Barron’s; WSJ).
Semis as a swing cohort: Taiwan trade/tariff clarity is a supportive idiosyncratic input, but it competes with broader AI-valuation/earnings-sentiment pressure (Reuters; FT).

dominant_driver.driver: US CPI downside surprise -> rates lower -> duration support

rates_policy_path.what_market_seems_to_price: Incremental dovish shift after CPI (higher odds of mid-year easing; magnitude described as modest).
rates_policy_path.what_might_be_underpriced: Re-acceleration risk from sticky services/shelter and/or tariff pass-through could reintroduce a higher real-rate regime quickly; also data-quality noise flagged by some outlets could amplify later revisions/interpretation risk.

equities_factor_tape.what_market_seems_to_price: CPI relief should support growth/duration factors, but the market is still digesting an AI-led risk reduction that broadened beyond pure AI winners into adjacent sectors.
equities_factor_tape.what_might_be_underpriced: Positioning/flow fragility (post-large sell imbalance) can overpower macro relief intraday; a second leg of tech de-grossing is plausible even with supportive rates.

gold.what_market_seems_to_price: Gold remains primarily tethered to inflation/real-rate expectations; softer CPI is supportive on the margin.
gold.what_might_be_underpriced: If the market interprets softer CPI as partly base-effect/noise, real yields could rebound quickly; also risk-off liquidation can temporarily pressure gold despite a dovish macro impulse.

fx_credit_liquidity.what_market_seems_to_price: No clear new systemic stress signal from provided inputs; focus remains on rates and equity factor volatility.
fx_credit_liquidity.what_might_be_underpriced: A sharper risk-off could widen credit spreads and tighten financial conditions faster than macro data implies, feeding back into equity multiples.

risk_register.risk: Interpretation risk: CPI downside surprise is partly base-effects; if subsequent prints re-accelerate, the market could rapidly unwind dovish repricing (rates up, NQ down; gold pressured via real yields).
AI/tech de-grossing persists despite CPI relief; factor rotation becomes disorderly, keeping NQ volatility elevated and correlation spikes in index futures.
Flow/positioning risk: after large sell-side close imbalances and a weak prior tape, intraday liquidity pockets can amplify moves around headline follow-through (rates + megacap).
Trade-policy headline risk remains two-sided: US–Taiwan agreement helps semis at the margin, but broader tariff escalation/retaliation remains a latent macro shock channel.

event_warnings: Post-CPI session risk: watch for second-order moves (real yields, USD) after the initial CPI impulse—this is the main determinant of whether ES/NQ can stabilize or re-break lower (WSJ; Reuters).
Market is coming off a heavy selloff day attributed to AI-disruption fears; even supportive CPI can produce “bad breadth” if participants use strength to reduce risk (Reuters; Yahoo Finance).
Semiconductor sensitivity: any further detail/interpretation around US–Taiwan tariff terms can create idiosyncratic index impacts via heavyweight chip names (Reuters; FT).
